stream_context.summary: The stream focused on redesigning the beginning of Course 1. Kaze replaced a simple pipe entrance with a new, interactive growing flower mechanic inspired by Yoshi's Island, changed the area's visual theme to a 'birdhouse' concept, and discussed plans for a public demo to gather feedback on the game's core physics and camera.

development_findings.summary: Kaze modified the game's sliding physics to remove the hard speed cap, allowing players to maintain high momentum when landing on a slide, which he believes feels better.
development_findings.quote: Usually in vanilla Mario 64 the sliding is hard capped at 100 speed... I soft capped it at 95, so when you're above 95 you asymptotically approach 95 by like 5% every frame.

development_findings.summary: The start of Course 1 is being redesigned from a simple pipe to an interactive, growing flower stalk that functions as an automatic, spinning elevator to a higher area.
The visual theme for the starting area of Course 1 was changed to a "birdhouse" concept, moving away from a less distinct nature theme.
Kaze has devised a technical plan to make the growing flower stalk appear infinite by using a combination of shade alpha gradients and cutout rendering to fade the top of the model into the skybox.
Kaze confirms the game will feature a large hub world, which he considers essential for a Mario 64-style game.
development_findings.quote: A hub world is very important for an R64 like, it's gluing the whole game together.

development_findings.summary: 100-coin stars have been removed from the game and replaced with six collectible Yoshi Coins per level, which can be gathered across missions without losing progress.
Kaze uses the NEMU emulator for difficult debugging tasks because it allows him to view the game's assembly code directly.
The team is consciously designing the game to be friendly for colorblind and deaf players.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses concern that his cognitive function has recently declined, speculating it might be a temporary effect of long-term stress.
context_findings.quote: Maybe I was just stressed out for so long that my brain functionality is temporarily reduced, which I believe is an effect, that can happen.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states that having a newborn daughter, who was born about four weeks prior to the stream, makes it very difficult to plan his schedule, explaining why he doesn't commit to bonus streams.
context_findings.quote: If you haven't noticed, I have a small child. That makes planning things really fucking difficult.

context_findings.summary: Kaze articulates a core design principle for the game: mechanics should be intuitive and integrated naturally into the world, rather than feeling like explicit puzzles.
context_findings.quote: When you make stuff like that, you can't just turn it into puzzles. You have to make it feel really natural.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to release a public demo of the first course specifically to gather player feedback on the new camera and physics systems before the full game's release.
context_findings.quote: I want more data on gameplay. I want more feedback for how people think the physics work and how the camera works and stuff like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses significant frustration with a recent update to Blender, stating its new vertex handling is worse than the controversy over the WebP image format.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided feedback in the chat that the colors in the level didn't "pop," which contributed to Kaze's decision to rework the area's visuals.
Kaze engages in playful banter with Biobak and Lilaa in the chat, indicating an informal and friendly team dynamic during live development.
biobak.quote: That's funny Biobak. Especially with the context of Lilaa losing her shit over this texture.

badub.summary: Kaze praises the music composed by Badub while working on the level.
badub.quote: I love this music too, the music's so good.

key_stories.title: The Growing Flower Mechanic
key_stories.summary: To solve a discoverability and design problem with a level entrance, Kaze collaborated with his community to replace a generic pipe with a unique growing flower mechanic. After prototyping revealed gameplay issues, he refined the concept into an automatic elevator, creating a more memorable and intuitive experience.
key_stories.challenge: The original entrance to a slide in Course 1 was a simple pipe inside a tree stump that players had trouble discovering, and it was thematically uninteresting.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed alternatives with his stream chat, considering a cannon and a vine before settling on a growing flower inspired by Yoshi's Island. He prototyped it in Blender and realized a manual climb would be too difficult and annoying. This led to the refined idea of an automatic, spinning elevator. He then devised a complex technical solution to make the stalk appear to grow infinitely into the sky.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a detailed plan for a new mechanic: a flower bud that grows into a giant, automatically spinning stalk, acting as an elevator. This solution is more visually interesting, thematically appropriate for Yoshi's Island, and incorporates clear, non-verbal cues for the player.
key_stories.key_quote: The problem is, how do you make the player know that they have to pull on it? That's my issue with that. And yes, the bunny can say that. But ideally, this level should be beatable without ever talking to anyone.

open_questions.context: Kaze plans to release a demo of Course 1 with a questionnaire to get feedback on physics and camera. He mentioned he's not good at writing questions and might use ChatGPT or ask "an actual human" for help.
